unnormalised: Heart health, you see, isn't just for old uncles sipping chai and complaining about the government. Even you, dear reader, are susceptible! Cardiology, the study of this vital organ, isn't all ECGs and stethoscopes. It's about keeping that ticker ticking happily, like a well-oiled auto-rickshaw engine. And let's face it, most of us treat our hearts worse than we treat our in-laws on Diwali. Dr. Sharma at AIIMS Delhi once told me, "Half my patients think their heart is made of mithai. It isn't!"

unnormalised: So, what's clogging those arteries more than bad Bollywood sequels? Firstly, samosas. Oh, sweet, greasy samosas! While delicious, each one is basically a deep-fried deposit in your coronary arteries. Secondly, stress. The pressure of finding a parking spot in Mumbai is enough to give anyone a heart attack, let alone dealing with office politics. A study in the Indian Heart Journal, Vol. 68, found that stress-induced cardiomyopathy is rampant, especially among software engineers pulling all-nighters. And let's not forget the 24x7 news cycle… watching Arnab Goswami shout could probably qualify as cardio (the bad kind).

unnormalised: Now, for some heart-healthy humor (because if you don't laugh, you'll cry... and that raises your blood pressure!). Imagine your heart as a stubborn elephant. You can't just tell it to run a marathon. You need to coax it with gentle walks, maybe some light yoga (no headstands after that third lassi!), and definitely avoid feeding it a bucket of ghee. Remember that time my cousin tried to bribe his heart with a month-long vacation in Goa after years of neglecting it? Let's just say his cardiologist, Dr. Iyer, wasn't amused. She suggested a healthier reward system involving less beachside vindaloo and more brisk walks.

unnormalised: But seriously, folks, take care of that precious pump. Incorporate some regular exercise, even if it's just walking to the nearest chai stall instead of taking an auto. Eat your veggies, even if they’re not as exciting as your grandmother's biryani. And for goodness sake, learn to meditate! Even 10 minutes of deep breathing can make your heart happier than winning a lottery of ₹1 Crore. Consider this article your friendly neighborhood heart's nag, reminding you to treat it right before it decides to go on strike and demands a written apology.

unnormalised: In conclusion, don't wait for your next birthday or Diwali to make some changes. Book a checkup with your local cardiologist (mine's Dr. Patel, highly recommended!), start small, and remember that a healthy heart is a happy heart. And a happy heart is one that will allow you to enjoy many more years of laughing at bad Bollywood movies, arguing politics over chai, and yes, even indulging in the occasional (but not excessive!) samosa. Your heart, after all, deserves a little bit of Bollywood drama too, just not the kind that ends with a cardiac arrest. Date of publication: 24/10/2024.
